name: spodumene production | spodumene | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7241/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of milled spodumene in the World. It is a copy of the AU dataset and so there may be larger uncertainty of the process data.

 The activity starts from spodumene in the ground.

This activites ends with the production of 1 kg of spodumene. The dataset includes the input of raw materials, machineries, energy consumption, emissions to air, and infrastructure of the site.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is from 2000 to 2012 (date of the publication including information on Lithium content)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset represents a copy of the dataset "spodumene production" covering geography AU. The uncertainty has been updated accordingly.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology for iron mining, crushing and milling for limestone production are assumed as a first approximation.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Most data are extrapolated from AU, based on the report by Hischier et al. 2007 (see published source)
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Approximation with data from literature. Amounts are mostly taken from the report by Hischier et al. 2007 (see published source). The amount of spodumene in ground and consequently the tailing amount is based on information about the lithium content in raw and concentrated ores from Stamp et al. (2012), from the mining site of Talison, Australia.

Reference:
Stamp, A., Lang, D. J., & Wäger, P. A. (2012). Environmental impacts of a transition toward e-mobility: the present and future role of lithium carbonate production. Journal of Cleaner Production, 23(1), 104-112.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value based on lithium content in pure spodumene in ground (LiAl(SiO3)2), i.e. 3.49% according to Stamp et al. 2012. Molecular weights: Li = 6.94 g/mol; Al = 26.98 g/mol; Si = 28.085 g/mol; O = 16 g/mol

Reference:
Stamp, A., Lang, D. J., & Wäger, P. A. (2012). Environmental impacts of a transition toward e-mobility: the present and future role of lithium carbonate production. Journal of Cleaner Production, 23(1), 104-112.
